text.p: Here are highlights from Polish newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
POLITICAL NEWS
RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Poland's senate has voted against removing grades in religion from certificates and diplomas issued by state-owned schools, which the Sejm, the lower house, passed in an act appended to the Concordat treaty with the Vatican.
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI

- The co-ruling coalition of the ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) and the Polish Peasants Party (PSL) is blocking a bill envisaging subsidies to companies which suffered as a result of recent floods, opposition centrist Union for Freedom (UW) front-bencher Tadeusz Syryjczyk said.
ECONOMIC AND MARKET STORIES
RZECZPOSPOLITA
- Poland's gross domestic product (GDP) will go up by 5.7 percent in 1997, a report by the cabinet's strategic studies centre (RCSS) said.

- The U.S.-Canadian Royal Europa firm plans to invest $54 million in building a plant making pre-fab-housing components in the special economic zone of Legnica, southwestern Poland, employing 500 workers.

- The privately-owned White Eagle airline will lease two Jak-40 aircraft from the Lietuva airline in Kaunas, Lithuania, to carry air-mail from Warsaw to Kaunas. Lietuva will receive monthly receive 140,000 lits from the contract.

- The Porion cable television and retail distribution chain operating in Poland, Sweden and Germany, has bought the Krotoszyn brewery in central Poland from Lech Browary Wielkopolski SA, the companies said.
- Poland's food prices in the last 10 days of July declined by 1.1 percent compared with the same period the month before, the Central Statistical Office (GUS) said.
- Telekomunikacja Polska SA, (TPSA), the state-owned telecoms monopolist, has contracted the US Motorola to build a radio access telecoms network in the Warsaw province worth $50 million, TPSA said.
- The Mewa garment maker in Bilgoraj, eastern Poland, will make a net profit in 1997 following several years of repaying debts to its creditors.
The plant will invest its profits into the modernisation of its production facilities to be completed by 2000.

- The Polish-Danish Prime-Food joint venture in Przechlew, northern Poland, will invest $34.6 million in the construction of a meat processing plant to produce annually 22,000 tonnes of beef and pork, Prime Food said.

- The Polmozbyt Rzeszow automotive firm, controlled by National Investment Fund (NFI) Victoria (No. 5), has sold a 51 percent stake worth 2.1 million zlotys in the Auto Res car dealer in Warsaw to the firm Carservice, Polmozbyt said.
- The Warta insurer plans to buy 50 percent stakes in two insurers controlled by Powszechny Bank Kredytowy (PBK), which is undergoing privatisation, a source who declined to be named said.
- Polish investors spent $30 million on shares in companies operating abroad in the first half of 1997, the National Bank of Poland (NBP), the central bank, said.
- The Brok brewery in Koszalin, northern Poland, starts trade on the Warsaw bourse on Thursday and expects its share price to exceed the issue price of 24 zlotys, Brok said.
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI
- Poland's government agenda for municipal housing development has contracted construction of 772 houses to be granted to flood victims in southwestern Poland.
- Poland's unemployment rate has declined to 11.4 percent and is 0.5 percent lower than envisaged by the 1997 forecast, Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz said.
The number of unemployed declined by 50,000 in July, Cimoszewicz said.

- The Elbrewery group in northern Poland consolidated all subsidiaries including Elbrewery Company, Hevelius and J.I. Marketing in June to cut costs and reduce product launching time, Elbrewery Company president Wieslaw J Skobrowski said.
GAZETA WYBORCZA
- Poland's industrial climate declined to 17 points by three points in July compared with the month before, a survey by the Warsaw School of Economics Economic Development Institute said.
